Here is the code of metal_finish_threads:

void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}

void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}

explanation: Only pointer declarations/usages that could be const-qualified are reported. The function parameter void *tids is never used to modify the pointed-at data, so it should be investigated as it could be declared const void * (or const pthread_t *). The local pointer pthread_t *tid_p and the explicit cast (pthread_t *)tids are related and should be investigated for the same reason. Other fragments (the null check if (!tids), the metal_log call, the loop and the pthread_join call) do not affect whether the pointer should be const-qualified: they either perform reads/joins or error reporting and do not modify the objects pointed to, so they do not need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
